para.phrase: LÚCIA MARTINS TEIXEIRA, MARIA DA GLÓRIA SIQUEIRA CARVALHO, RICHARD R. FACKLAM, AND PATRICIA LYNN SHEWMAKER

sect2.title: TAXONOMY
sect2.para: The genusEnterococcus includes microorganisms that have a historical connection with the genus Streptococcus, as they were initially considered a distinct branch within the genus Streptococcus, including most of the serological group D streptococci (see references 1–3 for a historical overview). Since the introduction of molecular methods, there have been considerable changes in taxonomy, which started with the splitting of the genus Streptococcus and the recognition of Enterococcus as a separate genus in 1984 (4). Indeed, as phylogenetic analyses based on the comparison of the 16S rRNA gene sequences evolved, members of the genus Enterococcus were found to be more closely related to certain other genera than to Streptococcus and Lactococcus, another genus with which they have been phenotypically associated (1–3, 5). Such observations culminated in the proposal to assign the genus Enterococcus to a newly designated family (Enterococcaceae fam. nov.) of the phylum Firmicutes, class Bacilli, order Lactobacillales, along with the genera Melissococcus, Tetragenococcus, and Vagococcus. Subsequently, three additional genera, Bavariicoccus, Catellicoccus, and Pilibacter, were assigned to this family (https://lpsn.dsmz.de/family/enterococcaceae) (6). Our knowledge about the phylogenetic relationships among these microorganisms is still evolving, and the current taxonomic arrangements may undergo additional amendments as more robust phylogenetic tools are available and are more extensively applied.

Like the other members of the familyEnterococcaceae, the genus Enterococcus is composed by Gram-positive, catalase-negative bacteria with DNA of low guanine-plus-cytosine content (G+C < 50 mol%). The enterococci are the most clinically important members of the family, since they are more frequently found in clinical specimens and are widely distributed in nature. These properties may account, at least in part, for the relative heterogeneity among these microorganisms, leading to the concept that Enterococcus is neither a phylogenetically nor a phenotypically coherent genus. The increasing use of molecular approaches in recent decades has led to the description of several new enterococcal species and engendered many nomenclatural changes, resulting in the present recognition of over 69 species assigned to the genus Enterococcus (as of July 2022; for further details, see references 1 and 5, as well as the List of Prokaryotic Names with Standing in Nomenclature [https://lpsn.dsmz.de/genus/enterococcus]). Enterococcus is the type genus of the family Enterococcaceae, and Enterococcus faecalis is the type species of the genus Enterococcus.

Current criteria for inclusion in the genusEnterococcus and for the description of new enterococcal species encompass a polyphasic approach resulting from a combination of different molecular techniques (frequently involving whole-genome sequencing [WGS], 16S rRNA gene sequencing, DNA-DNA hybridization, determination of DNA G+C content, fatty acid methyl esters chromatographic analysis, and whole-cell protein [WCP] profiling analysis) and phenotypic testing. Sequencing of the 16S rRNA gene is a practical and powerful tool in aiding the identification of enterococcal species, and it has been performed for all species of Enterococcus recognized to date, although limitations for differentiating a few enterococcal species have been documented (3, 5). Fig. 1 shows the phylogenetic relationships among the diverse species of Enterococcus based on the analysis of 16S rRNA gene sequences, which are available from the GenBank database (as of July 2022). Sequencing assays targeting other genetic determinants have increasingly been used as additional tools to assess the phylogenetic relationships among enterococcal species and to formulate the description of new species (for further details, see references 1, 3, and 5, and “Identification” below). Housekeeping genes coding for proteins involved in basic cellular functions, such as the phenylalanyl-tRNA synthase (pheS gene), the RNA polymerase α-subunit (rpoA gene), the RNA polymerase β-subunit (rpoB gene), and the ATP synthase α-subunit (atpA gene), are the most common targets for these sequencing approaches, based on the analysis of a single gene or multiple genes, under the format of multilocus sequence analysis (MLSA) of concatenated sequences (2, 3, 5). Comparative analysis of spectra generated by matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time of flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) has also been incorporated into the array of methodologies used for taxonomic purposes in more recent times (7–9).

figure.title: FIGURE 1 Phylogenetic tree based on comparative analysis of the 16S rRNA gene sequences showing the relationship among the type strains of the species included in the genus Enterococcus. Lactococcus lactis was used as an outgroup, and bootstrap values at the nodes are displayed as percentages. Black dots indicate the species that have been recovered from human sources.

sect2.title: DESCRIPTION OF THE GENUS
sect2.para: The members of the genusEnterococcus are Gram-positive, catalase-negative cocci that occur singly or are arranged in pairs, short chains, or as small irregular clusters (5). They do not form endospores. Cells are sometimes coccobacillary when Gram stains are prepared from growth on solid medium but tend to be ovoid and in chains when grown in liquid media, such as thioglycolate broth. After growth on blood agar media for 24 h, colonies are usually between 1 and 2 mm in diameter, although some variants may be smaller. About one-third of E. faecalis isolates are β-hemolytic on agar containing rabbit, horse, or human blood but nonhemolytic on agar containing sheep blood. Some isolates of E. faecalis and Enterococcus durans are β-hemolytic regardless of the type of blood used. The other species are usually α-hemolytic or nonhemolytic.

Enterococci are facultative anaerobes with a homofermentative metabolism that results in the production ofL-(+)-lactic acid as the major end product of glucose fermentation. Because of their ability to ferment a wide range of carbohydrates to lactic acid, the enterococci are referred to as typical lactic acid bacteria. Gas is not produced. Most enterococci usually grow at temperatures ranging from 10°C to 45°C, with optimum growth at 35°C to 37°C. The majority of the species grow in broth containing 6.5% NaCl, hydrolyze esculin in the presence of bile salts (bile-esculin [BE] test), and they also hydrolyze leucine-β-naphthylamide by producing leucine aminopeptidase (LAPase). Apart from all or some isolates of certain infrequently reported species (including Enterococcus bulliens, Enterococcus canintestini, Enterococcus cecorum, Enterococcus columbae, Enterococcus devriesei, Enterococcus dongliensis, Enterococcus hulanensis, Enterococcus moraviensis, Enterococcus nangangensis, Enterococcus pallens, Enterococcus pingfangensis, Enterococcus saccharolyticus, Enterococcus termitis, and Enterococcus viikkiensis), most enterococci hydrolyze L-pyrrolidonyl-β-naphthylamide (PYR) by producing pyrrolidonyl arylamidase (pyrrolidonase [PYRase]). Results for both LAP and PYR testing, especially for some of the more recently described species, may vary according to the methodology, including the test format and medium used to grow the bacterial cells.

A few species are motile (Enterococcus casseliflavus, Enterococcus gallinarum, and the more recently described species Enterococcus massiliensis and “Enterococcus timonensis”) by scanty flagella, and several are yellow pigmented (E. bulliens, E. casseliflavus, Enterococcus gilvus, Enterococcus innesii, “Enterococcus mediterraneensis,” Enterococcus mundtii, E. pallens, Enterococcus plantarum, Enterococcus rotai, Enterococcus sulfureus, and Enterococcus ureilyticus) (1, 3, 5). Methods used for detection of enterococcal motility must be selected carefully, as differences in motility due to the composition of the medium have been demonstrated (10). Enterococci are not able to synthesize porphyrins and, therefore, do not produce cytochrome enzymes (5, 11). However, cytochrome activity is sometimes expressed when certain strains of E. faecalis are grown on blood-containing agar media, and it is observed as a weak effervescence in the catalase test. Positive catalase testing has also been reported for strains of Enterococcus haemoperoxidus, Enterococcus silesiacus, E. plantarum, and E. bulliens (3, 7) when cultivated on blood-containing agar media.

Most enterococcal strains produce a cell wall-associated glycerol teichoic acid that is identified as Lancefield’s serological group D antigen. The DNA G+C contents range from about 32 to 45 mol%. The genome sizes are in the range of approximately 2.3 to 3.4 Mb (5, 12–14). WGS of E. faecalis V583 (15), the first vancomycin-resistant clinical isolate reported in the United States, was followed by WGS of several other strains of a variety of enterococcal species and has opened many lines of investigation to improve our understanding about the genus Enterococcus. The genomes of most species of Enterococcus have been sequenced and are available at specialized sites and databases, such as the NCBI (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genome), the Joint Genome Institute (JGI) Genomes OnLine Database (JGI GOLD) (https://gold.jgi.doe.gov), and the Type (Strain) Genome Server (TYGS) (https://tygs.dsmz.de).

The other genera of catalase-negative Gram-positive cocci and the characteristics that distinguish them from the enterococci are discussed inchapters 20 and 22. No phenotypic criteria are available for clearly distinguishing the genus Enterococcus unequivocally from other genera, since there are no distinct characteristics that are common to all enterococci. Additionally, some characteristics have not yet been reported for the more recently identified and lesser-known species or have been tested by different methodologies, impairing the comparison of results and generating inconsistencies in identification.

However, certain characteristics are usually found in the majority of the strains belonging to the most frequently isolated enterococcal species. Presumptive identification of a Gram-positive, catalase-negative coccus as anEnterococcus can be accomplished by demonstrating that the strain is positive for the BE, PYR, and LAP tests and grows in the presence of 6.5% NaCl and at 45°C. Because strains of Lactococcus, Leuconostoc, Pediococcus, and Vagococcus with phenotypic similarities have been isolated from human infections (16, 17), the presumptive identification of enterococci based only on BE reaction and growth in 6.5% NaCl broth can be erroneous. Demonstrating the presence of group D antigen by serological reaction may be helpful in the identification, although this antigen is detected in only about 80% of the enterococcal strains. On the other hand, members of the Streptococcus bovis-Streptococcus equinus complex, as well as pediococci and leuconostocs (16) and some vagococcal strains (17), can also react with anti-group D serum. Since certain characteristics traditionally considered typical for the genus do not apply to some atypical strains and to several of the more recently described species, the criteria mentioned above may exclude several isolates or species. The use of molecular identification methods, such as a PCR-based test having the tuf gene as a genus-specific target and MALDI-TOF MS, may be helpful in circumventing these difficulties by correctly identifying both typical and unusual Enterococcus isolates at the genus level (18, 19).

sect2.title: EPIDEMIOLOGY AND TRANSMISSION
sect2.para: Several intrinsic characteristics of the enterococci allow them to grow and survive in harsh conditions and colonize diverse ecological niches. These microorganisms are widespread in nature and can be found in soil, plants, water, food, and animals, including mammals, birds, insects, and reptiles (2, 3, 5, 20, 21). In humans, they are predominantly inhabitants of the gastrointestinal tract and are less commonly found in other sites, such as in the genitourinary tract, the oral cavity, and skin, especially in the perineal area. Enterococci are usually considered among the most abundant Gram-positive cocci colonizing the gastrointestinal tract of humans, with E. faecalis being one of the most common bacterial species recovered from this site (2, 20). Other species, such as Enterococcus faecium, E. casseliflavus, E. durans, and E. gallinarum, are also found in variable proportions. The diversity of species and size of enterococcal populations in the intestinal microbiome of humans appear to be influenced by age, diet, and other factors that may be related to changes in physiologic conditions, such as underlying diseases and prior antimicrobial therapy (2, 20).

Since the enterococci are opportunistic pathogens, the incidence of each species found in human infections probably reflects the distribution of the different species ofEnterococcus in the human gastrointestinal tract. This site is believed to represent the major reservoir for strains associated with disease; from this location they may spread to cause infections and can also disseminate to other hosts and to the environment (2, 22, 23). The presence of high numbers of enterococci in the feces, as well as their ability to resist different chemical and physical conditions and to survive in the environment, implies that the enterococci can be used as indicators of fecal contamination and of the hygienic quality of food, milk, and drinking water (2, 21, 24). The occurrence of enterococci as members of the intestinal microbiota of humans and the relationship between the presence of enterococci in foods and human safety have been extensively reviewed (2, 20, 21, 24–26).

Transmission of vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE) represents a major public health concern. Hospitalized patients with intestinal carriage of VRE appear to be the main reservoir of the organism and, once colonized, the patients remain so for weeks or months. Thus, as colonized patients leave the hospital, the possibility that transmission might occur in the community cannot be discounted. VRE can be disseminated by direct patient-to-patient contact or indirectly via transient carriage on the hands of health care personnel; contaminated medical instruments, such as glucose meters, blood pressure cuffs, electronic thermometers, electrocardiogram (ECG) monitors and wires; and environmental surfaces, such as patient gowns and linens, beds, bedside rails, overbed tables, floors, toilets, door knobs, and wash basins (22, 23). Besides surviving for long periods on environmental surfaces, these microorganisms are tolerant to heat, chlorine, and some alcohol preparations, enhancing the possibilities for transmission.

As a response to the rising rates of VRE colonization and infection in U.S. hospitals, the CDC’s Hospital Infection Control Practices Advisory Committee (HICPAC) had early on established guidelines with recommendations for preventing the spread of VRE (27), which were later reinforced when guidelines on the management of multidrug-resistant microorganisms, including VRE, were released (28). National guidelines have also been developed for use in different countries, and adherence has been reported to have a positive effect on VRE containment in hospital settings (29–32). Overall, the recommendations include prudent vancomycin use, implementation of surveillance procedures for early detection of VRE, and infection control procedures to limit cross-contamination, such as isolation precautions, hand washing, and education about transmission of VRE.

Although only a small percentage of colonized patients develop serious systemic enterococcal infections, intestinal colonization with VRE has been clearly associated with subsequent VRE infections. However, in certain specific clinical situations (i.e., liver transplant recipients, patients on chronic hemodialysis, and patients with hematological malignancies), VRE-colonized patients appear to be at increased risk for developing serious enterococcal infections (22, 23, 33–36). This underscores the importance of active surveillance in high-risk patient groups to prevent transmission and outbreaks.

While preventing VRE infection is a health care priority and results of several studies indicate that VRE screening and use of contact precautions are cost-effective, this approach remains a matter of debate, as it requires multiple strategies that may vary according to hospital settings (31, 32, 37–39). Further evaluations are needed to better define the impact and cost-benefit relationship of maintaining stringent prevention and control protocols to strengthen the available evidence (31, 40, 41). For additional discussions on the prevention and control of health care-associated enterococcal infections, see chapter 10.

sect2.title: CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE
sect2.para: The enterococci are commensal microorganisms that act as opportunistic agents causing a variety of infections in humans. Many of these infections have been suggested to arise from translocation of the enterococcal cells from their major site of colonization in the gastrointestinal tract. They most commonly cause infections in the urinary tract, bloodstream, endocardium, burn and surgical-site wounds, abdomen, biliary tract, catheters and other implanted medical devices (23, 33–35, 42). The ubiquitous presence of enterococci, however, requires caution in establishing the clinical significance of a particular isolate. Unnecessary work and potentially misleading laboratory reports should be avoided whenever possible, especially with respect to in vitro susceptibility testing decisions (see “Antimicrobial Susceptibilities” below). Over the last decades, enterococci have emerged from being considered virtually harmless bacteria to medically important, multiple antibiotic-resistant health care-associated pathogens that contribute significantly to patient morbidity and mortality, as well as to increasing health care costs. Changes in the dynamics of the host-commensal relationship, such as those promoted by the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics, host injury, or diminished host immunity, could allow these bacteria to gain access to extraintestinal host sites and cause infection. Therefore, elderly patients with serious underlying diseases and other severely ill immunocompromised patients who have been hospitalized for prolonged periods, who have been treated with invasive devices, and/or who have received broad-spectrum antimicrobial therapy are at higher risk for acquiring enterococcal infections (22, 27, 34–36, 42).

Several potential virulence factors have been identified in enterococcal isolates that may play a role in the pathogenesis of enterococcal infections, including the surface adhesins Esp (enterococcal surface protein) and aggregation substance (AS), secreted toxin cytolysin/hemolysin, secreted proteases gelatinase and serine protease, extracellular superoxide, MSCRAMM Ace (adhesin to collagen ofE. faecalis), E. faecalis antigen A (EfaA), enterococcal capsule, and cell wall polysaccharides (23, 43–46). Nevertheless, none has been established as a major virulence factor in humans. One mechanism by which the enterococci can deviate from their commensal behavior is through the acquisition of new traits that allow the bacterium to overcome host defenses and colonize new niches, as suggested by the identification of the E. faecalis pathogenicity island (PAI), which is more often present in strains causing infection than in commensal strains (14, 47). In this context, acquired antimicrobial resistance is considered one of the many traits that virulent enterococci possess more frequently than commensal isolates that allow members of this genus to survive for extended periods of time in the host or environment, leading to their persistence and role as prominent health care-associated pathogens (2, 22, 23, 37, 45, 47). In addition, enterococci can transfer resistance determinants to other bacteria, for example, staphylococci, which further increases the clinical importance of the enterococci.

The ability to form biofilms is an important virulence factor of these microorganisms, allowing colonization of inert and biological surfaces while protecting against antimicrobial substances and mediating adhesion and invasion of host cells (22, 23, 35, 37, 43, 44). Biofilm formation may be of particular importance in the development of endocarditis, endodontic and urinary infections, and infections associated with implants and other medical devices (34, 35, 42, 45, 48, 49).

The variety of infections associated with the enterococci has been thoroughly reviewed and summarized (33, 35). Although the spectrum of infections has remained relatively unchanged since the extensive review by Murray (33), trends toward increasing prevalence of these organisms as health care-associated pathogens have been frequently observed. Enterococci have become the second or third leading cause of nosocomial urinary tract infections (UTIs), wound infections (mostly surgical wounds, decubitus ulcers, and burn wounds), and bacteremia in the United States and many other parts of the world (33, 35, 50–53). UTIs are the most common enterococcal infections: enterococci have been implicated in approximately 10% of all UTIs and in up to approximately 16% of health care-associated UTIs, being identified as the third most frequent agent of uncomplicated UTIs and the second in complicated UTIs (33, 35, 51, 54). Enterococcal bacteremia is frequently associated with metastatic abscesses in multiple organs and high mortality rates and is often complicated by endocarditis.

Enterococci are estimated to account for approximately 15% to 20% of the cases of native valve bacterial endocarditis and for approximately 6 to 7% of prosthetic valve endocarditis. Endocarditis remains one of the most difficult-to-treat enterococcal infections because of limitations on bactericidal antimicrobial therapy for enterococcal infections, especially when caused by VRE (35, 44, 55, 56). Intra-abdominal and pelvic infections are also commonly associated with enterococci, and these microorganisms are recognized as one of the most common causes of tertiary peritonitis (33, 35, 57). However, cultures from patients with peritonitis, intra-abdominal or pelvic abscesses, biliary tract infections, surgical site infections, and endomyometritis are frequently polymicrobial, and the role of enterococci in these settings remains controversial. The significance of isolates from some of these sites should be carefully evaluated before clinical decisions are made.

The enterococci are also important causes of endodontic infections and infections associated with implanted medical devices (34, 35, 42). Infections of the respiratory tract or the central nervous system, as well as otitis media, sinusitis, septic arthritis, and endophthalmitis, may occur but are rare (33, 35).

The ratios of isolation of the different enterococcal species can vary according to each setting and can be affected by a number of factors, including the increasing dissemination of outbreak-related strains such as vancomycin-resistantE. faecium. E. faecalis and E. faecium are usually the most common enterococcal species isolated from human clinical specimens. Historically, E. faecalis represented about 80 to 90% of the clinically significant enterococcal isolates, while E. faecium was found in 5 to 10% of enterococcal infections (33, 58, 59). However, a trend toward a progressive decline in the ratio of E. faecalis to E. faecium is notable, particularly among isolates from bloodstream infections (2, 23, 51, 52, 60). About 22 other enterococcal species have been recovered from human sources, but their frequencies are much lower, even though clusters of infections associated with E. casseliflavus, E. gallinarum, and E. raffinosus have been reported (61–64). Other species that have sporadically been isolated from human sources are: E. avium, “E. burkinafasonensis,” E. caccae, E. canintestini, E. cecorum, E. dispar, E. durans, E. gilvus, “E. hawaiiensis,” E. hirae, E. italicus, “E. massiliensis,” E. malodoratus, “E. mediterraneensis,” E. mundtii, E. pallens, E. pseudoavium, E. thailandicus, and “E. timonensis.”

Although the enterococci can cause human infections in the community and in health care settings, these microorganisms began to be recognized with increasing frequency as common causes of health care-associated infections (HAIs) in the late 1970s, paralleling the increasing resistance to most currently used antimicrobial agents. A major impact on the incidence and epidemiology of enterococcal infections was noted after the first reports on the occurrence and epidemic increase of VRE in hospitals in the United States. From 1989 to 1999, the percentage of VRE isolates reported by U.S. hospitals increased from 0.3% to over 25% of allEnterococcus isolates (50). Since then, the enterococci have usually been listed as the second or third most frequent health care-associated pathogen isolated from ICU patients in the United States, depending on the type of infection.

In the 2015–2017 report from the National Healthcare Safety Network (NHSN) at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the enterococci were listed as the second most common antimicrobial-resistant pathogen associated with HAIs in adults, accounting for about 14.8% of the total cases of infection (51). In this report, about 10.7% of E. faecalis isolates and 78.3% of E. faecium isolates recovered from adult patients with central line-associated bloodstream infections in hospital wards were resistant to vancomycin. Among patients in long-term acute-care hospitals, VRE constituted 18.5% of the E. faecalis isolates and 84.4% of the E. faecium isolates (51). The European Antimicrobial Resistance Surveillance Network (EARS Net) of the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) also reported an increasing trend of the mean proportion of vancomycin-resistant E. faecium in invasive isolates from 11.6% in 2016 to 16.8% in 2020 in countries of the European Union and European Economic Area, with national percentages ranging from ≥1.0% to 56.6% (53). With increasing evidence of global spread, VRE were included in the so called ESKAPE pathogens (Enterococcus faecium, Staphylococcus aureus, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Acinetobacter baumannii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Enterobacter species), a group of antimicrobial-resistant bacteria that represent a global threat to human health (65).

The World Health Organization recognized VRE as one of the most significant resistant bacteria in its global priority list of antibiotic-resistant bacteria, released in 2017 in order to guide research, discovery, and development of new antibiotics (66). Additionally, in the more recent version of the document “Antibiotic Resistance Threats in the United States, 2019,” VRE is listed by the CDC as a continuous major serious public health threat that requires prompt and sustained action (67). According to data collected by the CDC, VRE caused an estimated 54,500 cases of infections among hospitalized patients, 5,400 estimated deaths, and an estimated $539 million in health care costs in the United States in 2017 (67).

sect2.title: COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, AND STORAGE OF SPECIMENS
sect2.para: The standard methods for collecting blood, urine, wound samples, and other secretions or swab specimens suspected of harboring enterococci are adequate (seechapter 18). No special methods or procedures are necessary for transportation and storage of clinical specimens containing enterococci, because these microorganisms are easily recovered and are relatively resistant to environmental changes and adverse conditions. Transport can be performed on almost any transport medium or on swabs that are kept dry. Like most clinical samples, the material should be cultured as soon as possible. VRE strains were shown to survive for 14 days in Amies medium when stored at 4°C or room temperature (68). Additionally, Amies medium was found to be more reliable than Stuart medium to transport rectal specimens for VRE detection by direct PCR testing (69), mentioned in the next section.

Enterococcal strains can be stored indefinitely when lyophilized. In our experience, cultures frozen at −70°C or less can be stored for several years as heavy cell suspensions made directly in defibrinated sheep or rabbit blood or in a skim milk (10%) solution containing glycerol (10%). These are the preferred methods for preservation of enterococcal strains. They can also be preserved for many years at −20°C in other cryopreservative media commonly used for maintenance of bacteria. Most strains of enterococci can survive for several months at 4°C on agar slants prepared with ordinary agar bases, such as brain heart infusion (BHI) agar and Trypticase soy agar. Certain of the less well-known species, however, are not as resistant to adverse conditions and may not survive long if adequate preservation procedures are not used.

sect1.title: Microscopy
sect1.para: The direct microscopic examination of Gram-stained smears of normally sterile clinical specimens, such as blood, may be useful for the diagnosis of enterococcal infections. Direct examination of certain nonsterile specimens may also be informative but should not be overemphasized. In any case, only a presumptive report of the “presence of Gram-positive cocci in pairs/chains” should be made, as microscopy by itself cannot differentiate the enterococci from most of the other Gram-positive cocci. Culture and appropriate identification techniques should be performed for confirmation.

sect1.title: Nucleic Acid Detection
sect1.para: As the occurrence of VRE continues to represent an important problem worldwide, hospitals are encouraged to implement surveillance programs for VRE detection (22, 23, 27, 35, 69). In an attempt to overcome the inherent limitations of the culture-based methods of detection (discussed in “Isolation Procedures” below), PCR-based methods have been evaluated for direct detection of these microorganisms in clinical and surveillance specimens (70–82). Nearly all the evaluation studies have reported improved detection of VRE in rectal swabs and fecal specimens over that obtained with conventional culture techniques, contributing to decreasing the time for detection and potentially reducing the risk of VRE transmission.

Among a number of molecular assays that are commercially available for detecting VRE, the LightCyclervanA/vanB detection assay (Roche Molecular Diagnostics, Indianapolis, IN) and the Cepheid Xpert vanA and Cepheid Xpert vanA/vanB assays (Cepheid, Sunnyvale, CA) are possibly the most frequently used (72–82). The Cepheid Xpert vanA assay is FDA cleared, and the Xpert vanA/vanB assay has received CE marking (the European Union’s mandatory conformity marking indicating that a product has met EU health, safety, and environmental requirements). Currently, the Roche LightCycler VRE detection kit is marketed as for research use only. It is important to note that these systems use proprietary sequences for detection of the van genes and sensitivities may vary.

Specificity is also a potential problem unless PCR controls for genus and/or species identification are included, becausevan genes, especially vanB, may be found in bacteria other than enterococci also present in the gut microbiota (73, 74, 76, 77, 79–82). The distribution of either vanA or vanB in particular populations will affect the specificity of the PCR test used to detect the van genes (76). This situation was demonstrated by investigators in Denmark who were able to use the Xpert vanA/vanB system to accurately follow the spread of vanA enterococci (78). These investigators concluded that despite the increased cost in laboratory supplies for the PCR-based test, savings incurred by reducing the patient isolation time made molecular testing cost-effective. The use of selective enrichment broth (discussed in “Isolation Procedures” below) has been used to address the specificity problem with the vanB portion of PCR-based systems for VRE identification (75, 77). Results indicated that the use of these assays on enriched broth cultures can be considered a useful and rapid tool for a more precise detection of vanB VRE. When selective enriched broths are used instead of direct rectal or fecal samples, these tests should no longer be considered direct testing.

Culture-independent assays for rapid detection and identification of enterococci directly in blood samples have been evaluated. A laboratory-developed real-time PCR assay for quantitative detection ofE. faecalis DNA in blood specimens without prior cultivation has been proposed for the diagnosis of bacteremia (83). The Magicplex sepsis real-time test (Seegene Technologies Inc., Walnut Creek, CA) is a multiplex real-time PCR designed to identify a variety of agents causing bloodstream infections, including E. faecalis, E. faecium, and E. gallinarum, as well as the antimicrobial resistance genes vanA and vanB (82, 84, 85). This test is available for use in Europe and other parts of the world, but it is not FDA cleared. The T2 bacterial panel assay (T2 Biosystems, Inc., Lexington, MA) was shown to be a promising tool to reliably identify E. faecium directly in whole-blood samples (86). The assay is performed on a fully automated T2Dx instrument platform that uses T2 magnetic resonance (T2MR) technology, and it is intended to enable multiplex detection of ESKAPE pathogens, which include E. faecium. This diagnostic test has already received CE marking and FDA clearance.

Multiplex droplet digital PCR and metagenomics-based assays have also been developed for the detection of bloodstream pathogens directly in blood samples (85, 87), but none of them has been extensively evaluated for the diagnosis of enterococcal infections. Two of them, the Hybcell pathogen DNA assay (CubeDx, St. Valentin, Austria) and the iDTECT Dx blood test (PathoQuest, Paris, France) are CE marked. As the technology behind these molecular methods evolves and improves, they may become widely available for the rapid and precise detection of enterococci directly in clinical samples. However, further evaluation is needed to determine the real impact of their use on laboratory diagnosis of invasive enterococcal infections and on patient management. Non-culture-based methods for pathogen detection from blood are covered more generally in chapter 5. Molecular methods for rapid detection directly from positive blood culture bottles are discussed below (see “Identification by Molecular Methods”).

sect2.title: ISOLATION PROCEDURES
sect2.para: The source of clinical specimens to be tested for the presence of enterococci influences the type of medium needed for primary isolation. Clinical specimens from normally sterile body sites can be plated directly onto a nonselective medium such as Trypticase soy agar, brain heart infusion agar, or another blood agar base containing 5% sheep, horse, or rabbit blood. In general, strains of the most clinically relevant species grow well at 35°C to 37°C and do not require an atmosphere containing increased levels of CO2, although some strains grow better in this atmosphere. Samples for blood culture can be inoculated into conventional blood culture systems. For clinical specimens obtained from nonsterile sites, especially those heavily contaminated with Gram-negative bacteria, use of selective media is a good option for primary isolation. In these cases, and particularly when enterococci may be present in low numbers, consideration must also be given to whether an enrichment broth should be employed. The use of a broth enrichment step in the primary isolation will delay the identification but will increase the recovery rates of enterococci. Many different media have been devised for selective isolation of enterococci, as previously reviewed (88).

The increasing incidence of vancomycin resistance among the enterococci has raised the importance of selective isolation of VRE. Early identification of infection or colonization by VRE is recommended to prevent the spread of these microorganisms (23, 33, 35, 69). Current recommendations for hospital infection control may include VRE fecal surveillance cultures. Different selective agar and/or broth medium formulations and several procedures have been employed for the isolation of VRE from sources containing normal microbiota, such as stool samples and rectal or perianal swab specimens. Most of them are variations of selective media that differ with regard to the antimicrobial agents or the antimicrobial concentrations used.

Although no consensus for a VRE isolation protocol has been established, the use of a selective-enrichment broth seems highly effective for enhancing the recovery of VRE. For this purpose, BHI broth has been used with vancomycin concentrations from 3 μg/ml to 30 μg/ml (71, 76, 88). Bile-esculin-azide (BEA) broth supplemented with vancomycin at concentrations of 4 μg/ml to 15 μg/ml (BEAV) (70, 80, 88–90) and Enterococcosel broth medium supplemented with concentrations of vancomycin from 4 μg/ml to 64 μg/ml (70, 76, 88–90) have also been used in a number of studies. One advantage that the bile-esculin based broth media have over BHI-based media is that media containing esculin turn black as the enterococci grow, and if the esculin-containing medium does not turn black, it can be assumed that no enterococci are present. Several studies report improved recovery of VRE from selective-enrichment broth over that of direct plating (88, 89, 91–93). Among the different concentrations of vancomycin used, 6 μg/ml is the most commonly used. In some of the protocols, various concentrations of other antimicrobial agents, such as aztreonam, meropenem, and clindamycin, have been used in the enrichment broth. There are no studies reporting extensive comparison of recovery rates of VRE from different selective-enrichment broths.

Media containing chromogenic substrates are available for the isolation and presumptive identification of enterococci (73, 81, 91–100). Table 1 lists chromogenic media that are commercially available, as well as the concentration of vancomycin in each. Most of these media allow for the identification of the two main vancomycin-resistant enterococcal species, E. faecalis and E. faecium. The chromogenic agars with FDA approval for use with human specimens are Brilliance VRE agar, ChromID VRE, CHROMagar VRE, Spectra VRE, and VRESelect medium (Table 1). Some chromogenic media that are selective for VRE have the advantage over the bile esculin-based selective media in that the colors of the colonies can help in the presumptive identification of VRE species. In some surveillance studies, selective enrichment was used prior to inoculation of the chromogenic agar, while in others, the clinical samples were directly inoculated onto the surface of the agar. It has been reported that in certain circumstances, some of these chromogenic agars may produce false-positive results. An investigation monitoring VRE in a neonatal intensive care unit using Spectra VRE showed that several vancomycin-susceptible enterococci grew on this medium (99).

In some circumstances, it may be necessary to recover VRE from environmental surfaces for epidemiological studies. Isolation of the organisms from these surfaces can be accomplished by swabbing the surfaces with premoistened swabs and placing them either into a selective-enrichment broth or onto selective agar plates.

Large-volume screening for VRE detection by using chromogenic culture media may take advantage of automation systems available in some diagnostic laboratories. For instance, the use of the WASPLab system (Copan, Brescia, Italy) has been evaluated for automated specimen processing and digital image reading analysis of chromogenic media for detection of VRE (98). Among a total of 104,730 rectal swab samples examined, automation agreed with manual analysis for 90.1% of all samples tested, with sensitivity and specificity of 100% and 89.5%, respectively (98). The results indicate the robustness of the system, and studies are needed to more accurately address comparisons of cost estimates and time differences to manual processing.

Culture-based screening methods for VRE may be especially demanding, can take several days to complete, and have variable degrees of sensitivity, all of which can impact the timely implementation of infection control procedures. Therefore, some microbiology laboratories have considered the introduction of molecular techniques to detect VRE to facilitate the rapid and accurate identification of these organisms and to improve sensitivity for detecting this pathogen in comparison with culture. However, many of the current approaches still depend on bacterial growth in culture prior to detection, requiring 24 h or more to complete. Consequently, the application of methods for a more rapid detection of VRE directly from clinical samples is still an area of significant interest for improvements (see “Direct Examination” above).

entry.para: E. casseliflavus/E. gallinarum: blue or inhibited
E. faecium: pink to light purple or navy blue

sect2.para: Furthermore, because a laboratory report of VRE can initiate a cascade of infection control events that are time-consuming and costly, laboratories must be certain of the epidemiological importance of any suspected VRE isolate. The transferable and high-level vancomycin resistance, especially that encoded by thevanA or the vanB genes, most frequently associated with E. faecalis and E. faecium isolates is the major focus of infection control efforts (see “Antimicrobial Susceptibilities” below). In contrast, the intrinsic low-level vanC resistance, which is not associated with wide dissemination of resistant strains, is less likely to be important for infection control surveillance efforts. While the isolation of VRE from clinical and surveillance specimens is important, the need for establishing protocols to rapidly determine the likely underlying mechanism of resistance (see “Antimicrobial Susceptibilities” below) is equally important.

sect1.title: Identification by Conventional Physiological Testing
sect1.para: Once it is established that an unknown catalase-negative Gram-positive coccus is anEnterococcus or closely related genus (see “Description of the Genus” above), the tests listed in Table 2 can be helpful in identifying the species. Most of the data presented in Table 2 for the phenotypic characteristics are derived from conventional testing (except for β-galactosidase) as performed at the CDC Streptococcus Laboratory (see https://www.cdc.gov/streplab/other-strep/general-methods-section1.html) to identify enterococcal isolates most frequently recovered from humans. Isolates from nonhuman sources, even those belonging to well-known species, may have different results in some tests. Moreover, the use of different methods for phenotypic testing may lead to results diverging from those shown in Table 2. Species that have not been recovered from humans to date are also included in Table 2, as the possibility exists that they may be isolated from human sources in the future. To date, only 24 of the 69 known species of Enterococcus have been recovered from human sources, the majority belonging to only two species: Enterococcus faecalis and Enterococcus faecium. Note that complete phenotypic testing data for some of the more recently proposed species are not yet available for inclusion in Table 2.

Enterococcal species can be initially separated into five physiological groups of species based on acid formation from mannitol and sorbose and hydrolysis of arginine (seeTable 2 for details). It is important to note that this classification in phenotypic groups of species is useful for diagnostic purposes but does not appear to reflect the phylogenetic relationships between Enterococcus species, so it does not necessarily correlate with 16S rRNA gene sequencing relationships. Identification of enterococcal species by conventional tests can be time-consuming and may require incubation of the tests for up to 10 days before a definitive identification can be reached. On the other hand, the majority of the isolates recovered from human sources can be identified after 2 days of incubation.

sect1.title: Identification by Commercial Systems
sect1.para: Several miniaturized, manual, semiautomated, and automated systems are commercially available and represent alternatives to conventional testing for the phenotypic identification of enterococcal species in routine diagnostic laboratories. Since their introduction, these systems have been updated to improve their performance characteristics and expand their identification capabilities, as investigators have become more aware of inaccuracies (1, 8, 18, 101, 102). In general, these systems are reliable for the identification of the most common species, E. faecalis, and, to a lesser extent, E. faecium. Precise identification of other species, by most systems, depends on additional testing, although improvements have been observed with updated formats and databases. Commercial systems available for the identification of enterococcal species include the API 20S and the API Rapid ID32 STREP systems (bioMérieux, Durham, NC), the Crystal Gram-positive and Crystal Rapid Gram-positive identification systems (Becton Dickinson Microbiology Systems, Sparks, MD), and the identification panels on automated systems, including the Vitek (bioMérieux), MicroScan (Dade MicroScan, West Sacramento, CA), and BD Phoenix (Becton Dickinson Microbiology Systems).

Overall, a large proportion of enterococcal isolates recovered from human sources will be accurately identified by most of the commercial systems now available; however, the accuracy is dependent on the distribution of species found in each specific setting. For example, the Vitek 2 system was found to identify 99.2% and 91.7% of a set ofEnterococcus isolates at the genus and species level, respectively, but only 76% of the E. casseliflavus and E. gallinarum isolates were correctly identified at the species level (102). These figures are in general agreement with our observations by using the Vitek 2, indicating a lower efficiency in discriminating E. casseliflavus from E. gallinarum, E. avium from E. raffinosus and E. pseudoavium, and E. durans from E. hirae and E. faecium (our unpublished data). Difficulties in the identification of a variety of enterococcal species, sometimes including E. faecalis and E. faecium, have been reported (18, 81, 102–104). Strict adherence to the instructions provided by the manufacturer, including the media used to grow strains for testing, is of paramount importance. Our own unpublished experimental results indicate that differences in growth conditions can lead to variation in the results of some tests, interfering with the accuracy of the identification. Additionally, the discriminatory limits of each system, as usually specified in the instructions by the manufacturer, should always be taken into consideration. Identification of an unusual enterococcal species by a commercial system should be confirmed by a reference method before being reported.

sect1.title: Identification by MALDI-TOF MS
sect1.para: In the last few years, MALDI-TOF MS has been considered a revolutionary tool for bacterial identification in the clinical microbiology laboratory, by providing rapid, accurate and highly convenient identification of a wide range of microorganisms, including enterococcal species (102–104). Two major MALDI-TOF MS platforms are available at this time: the Microflex LT Biotyper (Bruker Daltonics, Bremen, Germany) and the Vitek MS system (bioMérieux, Marcy l’Etoile, France). Data on the evaluation of these platforms indicate that they are able to identify correctly most of the enterococcal isolates tested (102–105). However, at this point, extensive evaluation of either system, including all the different enterococcal species, is still not available, and E. faecalis, E. faecium, E. casseliflavus, and E. gallinarum remain the species more extensively tested by this methodology. Although the numbers of studies and enterococcal species tested are still limited, the results indicate that the method constitutes an important tool to rapidly identify the major enterococcal species recovered from human sources and certainly deserves to be further evaluated for the identification of the diverse members of the genus Enterococcus, including isolates with a variety of biochemical profiles and obtained from different sources. In addition, MALDI-TOF MS has also been applied directly on positive blood cultures and urine cultures, providing more rapid results (106, 107), but these methodologic approaches may need to be further evaluated and improved before being adopted as routine procedures for the diagnosis of enterococcal infections.

sect1.title: Identification by Molecular Methods
sect1.para: Molecular methods, such as DNA-DNA hybridization and sequencing of the 16S rRNA genes, have been primarily used for taxonomic purposes in reference or research laboratories. In recent decades, however, the application of molecular techniques for the rapid identification ofEnterococcus species has also been expanded dramatically for use in clinical microbiology laboratories.

A variety of molecular procedures have been proposed for the identification of enterococcal species, as previously reviewed and summarized (1, 2, 5, 88). Many of these molecular procedures have been performed in only a few laboratories and have not been evaluated for all species of Enterococcus. Most of them are potentially applicable to all enterococcal species, and others are species specific. Several of these methods deserve consideration for expanded testing and future improvements, as they represent promising adjunct tools for a more rapid and precise identification of enterococcal species.

Most of the data presented inTable 2, which describes the phenotypic characteristics of the Enterococcus species discussed in this chapter, are based on correlations between results of phenotypic tests and analysis of WCP profiles, in conjunction with DNA-DNA reassociation experiments and 16S RNA gene sequencing (1, 5, 108). Sequencing of the 16S rRNA gene is currently the most frequently used among the nucleic acid-based methods for identification of enterococcal species. It has been performed for all species of enterococci, and the sequences are available for comparison purposes via public databases of nucleotide sequences, such as GenBank. Comparisons can be made by using one of the several sequence-comparing software packages, many of which are available for public access. Figure 1 depicts a dendrogram generated by comparison of 16S rRNA gene sequences of the type strains of the species included in the genus Enterococcus. Nevertheless, clear-cut differentiation is not always obtained for all enterococcal species, such as E. casseliflavus and E. gallinarum, since some of them differ by only 2 or 3 bases over the approximately 1,500-base span of the 16S rRNA gene. Therefore, this procedure should not be used alone, but, together with phenotypic characterization and other alternative molecular methods, it can be an important tool to establish enterococcal species identity. Several other housekeeping genes have been investigated as alternative tools to develop sequencing-based methods to identify enterococci, either alone or in association. They include the atpA, pheS, rpoA, and rpoB genes, as well as sodA (coding for the manganese-dependent superoxide dismutase) and tufA (coding for the elongation factor Tu) (2, 3, 109). Their use has mostly been restricted to taxonomic purposes, and none has been systematically applied to all the enterococcal species described to date. However, as genome sequence databases continue to grow and the costs of DNA sequencing decrease, genome-based methodologies may constitute useful tools to identify Enterococcus isolates in diagnostic laboratories.

PCR-based techniques have also been a focus of major interest for rapid and accurate enterococcal identification. Tests based on the amplification of the gene encoding theD-Ala–D-Ala ligase (ddl) (18, 103, 110) or the sodA gene (18) have already been designed for several enterococcal species and constitute convenient alternative approaches for rapid routine identification. However, PCR methods based on these targets are not available to identify all the enterococcal species yet.

The use of molecular methods for the rapid identification of enterococci directly from positive blood culture bottles has also been investigated. Fluorescencein situ hybridization (FISH) techniques have been developed and evaluated for the identification of enterococci from positive blood culture bottles (111, 112). Two of these FISH assays are FDA cleared and presently available from OpGen, Inc. (Rockville, MD). One of them is the E. faecalis/other Enterococcus species (EF/OE) peptide nucleic acid (PNA) FISH test, which offers a turnaround time to reliable results of 1.5 h and has 100% sensitivity and specificity (111). The other method is the Enterococcus QuickFISH BC, a second-generation PNA FISH test which incorporates several time-saving innovations, resulting in a simplified, faster assay procedure. It enables differentiation of Enterococcus faecalis from other Enterococcus spp. in 20 to 25 min (112). Other commercially available diagnostic systems based on nucleic acid technologies that have been cleared by the FDA include the Verigene Gram-positive blood culture (BC-GP) nucleic acid test (Nanosphere, Inc., Northbrook, IL) (113, 114), the BioFire FilmArray blood culture identification (BCID) panel (BioFire Diagnostics, Inc., Salt Lake City, UT) (115–117), and the ePlex blood culture identification Gram-positive (BCID-GP) panels (GenMark Diagnostics, Inc., Carlsbad, CA) (118).

These multiplex tests are capable of detecting most leading causes of bloodstream infections due to Gram-positive bacteria, including enterococci, as well as the genetic markers of vancomycin resistancevanA and vanB. Typically, only these two antimicrobial resistance-associated targets (vanA and vanB) are included on the molecular detection panels, and this constitutes a limitation of these systems due to their inability to detect vancomycin resistance genes other than vanA or vanB. Overall, they have been considered relatively easy to implement, leading to earlier identification of invasive infections caused by Enterococcus species in comparison with conventional microbiological methods. Therefore, these technologies can also have a significant impact on clinical and economical outcome of patients with enterococcal bacteremia, by decreasing the time to antimicrobial therapy, the length of hospital stay, and health care costs. For discussions of the impact and performance of these molecular diagnostic technologies, see references 117 and 119.

sect2.title: TYPING SYSTEMS
sect2.para: The documentation ofEnterococcus as a leading nosocomial pathogen frequently resistant to several antimicrobial agents, as well as the evidence supporting the concept of exogenous acquisition of enterococcal infections, has generated demands for strain typing and epidemiologic studies. Classic phenotypic methods used to investigate the diversity among isolates of a given enterococcal species have frequently failed to adequately discriminate among strains, and they have limited value in epidemiological studies. However, phenotypic information in association with molecular data can constitute valuable information (1, 5, 88).

Several molecular methods to type enterococcal isolates have been proposed, as previously reviewed (1, 3, 5, 88). In addition to differences in complexity and costs, these methods vary in their reproducibility and discriminatory power. Overall, there is not a single definitive typing technique for enterococci, so a strong match among the results of different typing techniques, particularly those based on different genomic polymorphisms, should be interpreted as indicative of close relatedness. Use of these techniques has substantially improved the ability to distinguish enterococcal isolates from one another within a given species and provided critical insights into the epidemiology of the enterococci. By using molecular typing approaches, the exogenous acquisition of enterococcal strains by direct and indirect contact among patients was demonstrated, breaking the traditional conception that enterococcal infections were endogenous. Intrahospital transmission and interhospital spread have been extensively documented for antimicrobial-resistant enterococci, especially VRE (1, 23, 35, 120–122). In addition to epidemiological investigations, some molecular typing techniques are now used to trace the dissemination of enterococci in different environments and hosts and the evolution of multidrug-resistant strains, greatly expanding our understanding of enterococcal epidemiology, population structure, antimicrobial resistance, and virulence. Emergence and global dispersion of certain epidemic enterococcal lineages and clonal complexes have been identified (2, 47, 60, 121–125).

Among these techniques, analysis of chromosomal DNA restriction profiles by pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) has been extensively evaluated for epidemiological characterization of enterococcal outbreaks, showing high discriminatory power and allowing the identification of clonal groups that predominate among multidrug-resistant enterococci, mainly isolates with high-level resistance (HLR) to aminoglycosides and VRE (1–3, 61–63, 120, 123, 124). For a long time, PFGE was considered the gold standard for epidemiological analysis of enterococcal outbreaks, although the lack of standardized protocols for execution, interpretation, and nomenclature constituted difficulties for interlaboratory data exchange and comparisons. Additionally, the occurrence of genetic events can be associated with substantial changes in the PFGE profiles, leading to difficulties in clonality assessment (126). Therefore, PFGE is recommended mostly for the purpose of evaluating the genetic relatedness and tracing transmission of strains that are associated in time and location, as its usefulness for long-term epidemiological studies may be limited. Use of PFGE in conjunction with at least one additional typing technique is recommended to help in clarifying epidemiological interpretation. General principles proposed for the interpretation of molecular typing data based on fragment differences are usually applied to interpret PFGE profiles obtained for enterococcal strains (1, 127).

Subsequently, two other molecular techniques were developed for typing enterococci and shown to be suitable for their assignment into distinct clonal complexes: multilocus sequence typing (MLST) and multiple-locus variable-number tandem repeat analysis (MLVA). These techniques circumvent the difficulties in data exchange between different laboratories by generating information that is suitable for the development of web-based databases. Despite its overt advantages (being reproducible, portable, highly discriminatory, and unambiguous), MLST is time-consuming, expensive, and still limited to laboratories that have facilities for both PCR and sequencing, while MLVA requires PCR and basic electrophoresis facilities. Comparative studies indicated that both techniques can achieve high degrees of discrimination between isolates and have discriminatory power comparable to that of PFGE-based typing (120, 128, 129), while in some other studies, MLVA was found to be less discriminatory than PFGE and MLST (130).

Two simultaneously published studies described the development of MLVA typing schemes forE. faecalis (131) and E. faecium (132). MLVA is based on variation in variable-number tandem repeat (VNTR) loci dispersed over the enterococcal genome. For each VNTR locus, the number of repeats is determined by PCR using primers based on the conserved flanking regions of the tandem repeats. PCR products are separated on agarose gels, and the band size determines the number of repeats. These numbers together result in an MLVA profile, and each profile is assigned an MLVA type (MT). Assignment to a given MT was performed by comparison with specific databases, which were discontinued a few years ago, making difficult the continuity of the MLVA nomenclature and the application of this technique.

On the other hand, MLST quickly replaced PFGE as the gold standard for typing enterococcal isolates. MLST is based on identifying alleles after sequencing of internal fragments of a number of selected housekeeping genes, resulting in a numeric allelic profile. Each profile is assigned a sequence type (ST). One of the major advantages of MLST is the possibility of using standard protocols and nomenclature and the establishment of databases that are accessible online, which are fundamental for studying the global spread and long-term transmission of strains. MLST schemes have been designed forE. faecium (133) and E. faecalis (129), and respective databases are found at https://pubmlst.org/organisms/enterococcus-faecium and https://pubmlst.org/organisms/enterococcus-faecalis. Application of MLST has revealed the occurrence of distinct clones associated with hospital infections/outbreaks, named high-risk enterococcal clonal complexes (HiRECCs), within populations of both E. faecalis and E. faecium (14).

Early applications of MLST indicated the occurrence of host-specific genogroups ofE. faecium and allowed the recognition of a large cluster of hospital-adapted E. faecium polyclonal subpopulation that predominated in several geographic areas, and this cluster was associated with the increased frequency of isolation of E. faecium worldwide (14, 23, 60, 121, 122, 134). This hospital-adapted subpopulation was initially designated the C1 lineage and later renamed clonal complex 17 (CC17), and thereafter, it was considered a major example of the so-called HiRECC of E. faecium.

Comparisons of available genome sequences supported the concept of a hospital-associated clade that is genetically distinct from most commensal isolates (134, 135). However, the assumption that CC17 isolates emerged from a single “founder” ST was contested when the analyses of the genetic relatedness of E. faecium MLST data was performed with Bayesian analysis of genetic population structure (BAPS) software instead of the eBURST algorithm initially used (see references 14 and 135 for details). According to this line of interpretation, E. faecium isolates can be placed in two genomically distinguishable groups, descending from ST17, -18, and -78, referred to in the literature as “lineages” or “clades”: a hospital-associated lineage (clade A) and a community-associated lineage (clade B). Clade A is further split into clade A1, represented by human clinical isolates, and several non-A1 subclades that, together with clade B isolates, are rarely found in hospitalized patients. In a recent proposal, clade B isolates have been reassigned to the species Enterococcus lactis (136). In contrast to the pronounced clade structure of E. faecium, the population structure of E. faecalis was found to be less discrete (14, 120, 129). Analysis of E. faecalis isolates from different sources and geographic locations revealed a variety of different STs that grouped into four major clonal complexes (CC2, CC9, CC10, and CC21) by using eBURST. Two of these major E. faecalis HiRECCs, CC2 and CC9, identified by MLST are particularly found among hospital-derived isolates (14, 120, 129).

More recently, as whole-genome sequencing has become more widely available and less expensive, application of WGS analysis is also becoming a robust alternative approach for typing of bacterial isolates. Advantages of using this technology, in conjunction with a diversity of informatics tools and pipelines, for genotyping enterococcal isolates and the consequent impact on our understanding on the epidemiology of enterococcal infections have been documented (123, 137–142). Although many current WGS-based typing approaches still lack standardization, several surveillance groups have been transitioning to WGS-based approaches, and core genome multilocus sequence typing (cgMLST) is possibly the most popular among these new sequence typing methods for enterococci. cgMLST schemes have been proposed for both E. faecium (137) and E. faecalis (140) and were shown to combine the discriminatory power of classical MLST with the extensive genetic data obtained by WGS.

The use of MALDI-TOF MS as a tool for fast molecular typing of enterococcal isolates has also been investigated. In one study, MALDI-TOF MS analysis was able to differentiate hospital-associatedE. faecium isolates from other strains of E. faecium but failed to identify lineage-specific biomarker peaks, thus rendering the discriminatory power of MALDI-TOF MS insufficient for reliable subdifferentiation of E. faecium to the level of distinct clones or clonal complexes, as can be achieved by MLST (143). In another study, comparing the use of MALDI-TOF MS and WGS in a VRE outbreak investigation, discrepancies between findings indicated the limitations of MALDI-TOF MS and the interpretation of MALDI-TOF MS dendrograms during outbreaks (144). Two more recent studies compared MALDI-TOF MS and PFGE and reported promising results. In one, the results indicated that MALDI-TOF MS was valuable for real-time outbreak detection and management despite lower resolution than PFGE (124). In the other, a cutoff value for mass spectrometry results was determined for typing VRE isolates by using MALDI-TOF MS, and the method was found to have sensitivity equal to that of PFGE (145). The main advantage of MALDI-TOF MS technology over the others is the much shorter analysis, which lasts only a few hours rather than several days, but improvements are still needed to establish MALDI-TOF MS protocols for accurate and practical typing of enterococcal isolates.

sect2.title: SEROLOGIC TESTS
sect2.para: Serologic tests, in the form of Western blot assays, for detecting antibody responses to different enterococcal antigens have been proposed (146, 147), but their usefulness in the clinical laboratory setting for the diagnosis or prognosis of enterococcal infections has not been demonstrated. On the other hand, certain antigens of E. faecalis and E. faecium were found to elicit the production of protective opsonic antibodies, indicating that they are promising targets for development of active or passive vaccination to add to the armamentarium to fight these important nosocomial pathogens (43, 148–150).

sect2.title: ANTIMICROBIAL SUSCEPTIBILITIES
sect2.para: Resistance to several commonly used antimicrobial agents is a remarkable characteristic of most enterococcal species, particularlyE. faecalis and E. faecium, the species that are more frequently associated with human infections. Antimicrobial resistance can be classified as either intrinsic or acquired. Intrinsic resistance is related to inherent or natural chromosomally encoded characteristics present in all or most of the enterococci. Furthermore, certain specific mechanisms of intrinsic resistance to some antimicrobial agents are typically associated with a particular enterococcal species or groups of species. In contrast, the occurrence of acquired resistance is more variable, resulting from either mutations in existing DNA or acquisition of new genetic determinants carried on plasmids or transposons (23, 33, 35, 151). Enterococcal intrinsic resistance involves several antimicrobial agents, particularly two major groups: the aminoglycosides and the β-lactams. Because of the poor activity of several antimicrobial agents against enterococci due to intrinsic resistance, the recommended therapy for serious infections (i.e., endocarditis, meningitis, and other systemic infections), especially in immunocompromised patients, includes a combination of a cell wall-active agent, such as a β-lactam (usually penicillin or ampicillin) or vancomycin, and an aminoglycoside (usually gentamicin or streptomycin). These combinations overcome the intrinsic resistance exhibited by the enterococci, and a synergistic bactericidal effect is generally achieved, since the intracellular penetration of the aminoglycoside is facilitated by the cell wall-active agent.

In addition to the intrinsic resistance traits, enterococci have acquired different genetic determinants that confer resistance to several classes of antimicrobial agents, including chloramphenicol, tetracyclines, macrolides, lincosamides and streptogramins, aminoglycosides, β-lactams, glycopeptides, quinolones, and even some of the more recently available drugs, such as linezolid, daptomycin, and quinupristin-dalfopristin (22, 23, 37, 151, 152). During the past several decades, the occurrence of acquired antimicrobial resistance among enterococci, especially HLR to aminoglycosides, β-lactams, and resistance to glycopeptides (especially vancomycin), has been increasingly reported. Isolates that are resistant to the cell wall-active agent or have HLR to aminoglycosides are resistant to the synergistic effects of combination therapy. Therefore, the detection of resistance to these groups of antimicrobial agents is critical in order to predict the likelihood of achieving synergy by using antimicrobial combinations as a therapeutic strategy. Enterococcal isolates exhibiting HLR to aminoglycosides are now present in large proportions in several geographic areas (22, 23, 35, 51, 52, 151, 152). Such strains frequently have MICs of >2,000 μg/ml and cannot be detected by diffusion tests with conventional disks. Special tests using high-content gentamicin and streptomycin disks, as well as a single dilution method, were developed to screen for this type of resistance (1, 153) (see chapters 72 and 74).

Strains exhibiting high-level resistance to penicillin and ampicillin due to altered penicillin-binding proteins have also disseminated widely (22, 23, 33, 37, 59, 151, 152), while strains producing β-lactamase have been rarely identified (33, 59, 152). Results of susceptibility testing with ampicillin may be used to predict susceptibility to amoxicillin, amoxicillin-clavulanate, ampicillin-sulbactam, piperacillin, and piperacillin-tazobactam among non-β-lactamase-producing enterococci. Ampicillin susceptibility can also be used to predict imipenem susceptibility, provided that the species is E. faecalis (153). However, enterococcal susceptibility to penicillin cannot be predicted on the basis of ampicillin testing results. If penicillin results are needed, testing of penicillin is required. On the other hand, enterococci susceptible to penicillin are predictably susceptible to ampicillin and the other β-lactams mentioned above. Penicillin and ampicillin resistance due to β-lactamase production is not reliably detected by routine disk or dilution methods but is detected by using a nitrocefin-based β-lactamase test (1, 153).

The emergence of acquired vancomycin resistance as a therapeutic problem among enterococcal isolates was first documented in Western Europe (154, 155). Thereafter, the isolation of VRE has been continuously reported, showing epidemic proportions in diverse geographic locations (22, 23, 33, 37, 59, 150, 152, 156). VRE strains have been classified according to phenotypic and genotypic features (Table 3). Ten types of resistance to glycopeptides have been described to date among enterococci. Each type is associated with different genetic elements, some of which, in turn, can be divided into subtypes. Three of them are the most common: the VanA phenotype, with inducible high-level resistance to vancomycin as well as to teicoplanin, encoded by the vanA gene; the VanB phenotype, with variable (moderate to high) levels of inducible resistance to vancomycin only, encoded by the vanB genes; and the VanC phenotype, encoded by the vanC genes, conferring constitutive low-level resistance to vancomycin. VanA and VanB are considered the most clinically relevant phenotypes and are usually associated with E. faecium and E. faecalis isolates, while VanC resistance is an intrinsic characteristic of E. gallinarum (vanC1 genotype) and E. casseliflavus (vanC2 to vanC4 genotypes) (35, 37, 151, 156, 157). The additional types of glycopeptide resistance, encoded by the vanD, vanE, vanG, vanL, vanM, vanN, and vanP genes (122, 151, 157, 158), seem to occur rarely among enterococci. Furthermore, the isolation of vancomycin-heteroresistant (159) as well as vancomycin-dependent (160) and vancomycin-tolerant (161) enterococcal strains from clinically significant sources, although sporadically reported, may also represent additional serious threats for the treatment and control of enterococcal infections (152, 162).

Whilein vitro methods for detecting vancomycin resistance are discussed in detail in references 1, 152, 153, and 163, as well as in chapters 72 and 74, some aspects of vanC-containing species (e.g., E. gallinarum and E. casseliflavus) need to be emphasized. Resistance associated with vanC genotypes is not usually detected by disk diffusion, but VanC strains frequently grow on vancomycin agar screen tests. Because of the low clinical significance of VanC resistance, the implications of susceptibility testing for patient management may be unclear. However, the need to differentiate VanA or VanB strains, as well as strains displaying the other less commonly found types of acquired vancomycin resistance, from VanC strains is quite evident for therapeutic, infection control, and surveillance reasons. Because growth on vancomycin screening agar fails to help with this important distinction, species identification is necessary. For practical purposes, growth on the vancomycin screening agar test by E. faecalis or E. faecium is likely due to the presence of vanA or vanB. Although rare, the occurrence of the other kinds of vancomycin resistance may also be considered. Additionally, simultaneous occurrence of the vanA gene has been increasingly reported in vanC-carrying species, E. casseliflavus and especially E. gallinarum, so that identification of a species that usually harbors only VanC resistance does not completely rule out moderate to high levels of vancomycin resistance (62). In this regard, determining vancomycin MICs is useful, as VanC resistance frequently results in MICs of <32 μg/ml, whereas VanA and VanB usually result in MICs of >32 μg/ml. In such cases, determination of the genetic elements associated with vancomycin resistance has important epidemiological and infection control implications. Also, resistance to other agents such as ampicillin and aminoglycosides is less common among VanC isolates.

Development of resistance to several currently available drugs highlights the difficulties facing clinicians in the setting of certain enterococcal infections and requires the use of new or innovative therapeutic approaches that involve both old and new antimicrobials. Because of limited alternatives, chloramphenicol, erythromycin, tetracycline (or doxycycline or minocycline), and rifampin may be tested for VRE. Selective testing of quinupristin/dalfopristin, linezolid, tigecycline, and daptomycin, based on the site of infection, is recommended for reporting of vancomycin-resistantE. faecium (151, 152).

Molecular methods (seechapter 78) have been used to detect specific antimicrobial resistance genes and have substantially contributed to the understanding of the spread of acquired resistance among enterococci, especially resistance to vancomycin. An appendix table is included in the CLSI M100 document highlighting strategies for reporting vancomycin results for Enterococcus spp. on the basis of both genotypic and phenotypic susceptibility testing methods (153). However, because of their high specificity, molecular methods will not detect antimicrobial resistance due to mechanisms not targeted by the testing, including emerging resistance mechanisms, or to mutations resulting in nonfunctional or unexpressed van genes, leading to discrepancies between results of genotypic and phenotypic testing (152, 164, 165).

Although increasing resistance has led to the recognition of the enterococci as a serious public threat and of the importance of their rapid and precise detection to evaluate and compare the global burden of resistance at the international level, there are still many limitations on accuracy, reproducibility, and even feasibility of antimicrobial susceptibility testing. Furthermore, CLSI and EUCAST have different recommendations for a variety of parameters that impact the interpretation and impair comparison of results with regard to clinically relevant antimicrobials. Therefore, the need for harmonization of testing and reporting guidelines is of importance in an era of global antimicrobial resistance and is a growing public health concern.

Some of these discrepancies among CLSI and EUCAST are related to differences in antimicrobial disk concentrations (for ampicillin, gentamicin, linezolid, nitrofurantoin, vancomycin, and teicoplanin, among others) and the availability of breakpoints for some antimicrobial agents by CLSI but not by EUCAST and vice versa. For example, breakpoints for daptomycin, fosfomycin, penicillin, and tetracycline have been proposed by CLSI but not by EUCAST, whereas imipenem and tigecycline breakpoints have been presented by EUCAST but not by CLSI. Most of these issues were extensively addressed in a recent review discussing conventional antimicrobial susceptibility testing of enterococci based on classical culture-dependent methods performed either manually or by using automated and semiautomated systems, as well as on molecular detection methods (152). Important discussions involving either specific (166) or more general (164, 165) topics on enterococcal susceptibility testing are also provided in recent publications.

sect2.para: aA genotype, designated vanP, coding for an novel type of vancomycin resistance (VanP), was recently described in E. faecium, but most of the characteristics listed in this table are not available yet (159).
bR, resistant; S, susceptible; I, intermediate.
cSubtypes include vanB1 to vanB3, vanC1 to vanC4, vanD1 to vanD5, and vanG and vanG2.
dD-Ala–D-Lac, D-alanine–D-lactate; D-Ala–D-Ser, D-alanine–D-serine.
eProduct deduced but not confirmed.

sect2.title: EVALUATION, INTERPRETATION, AND REPORTING OF RESULTS
sect2.para: The diversity and species specificity of acquired antimicrobial resistance traits among enterococcal isolates created an additional need for accurate identification at the species level and forin vitro evaluation of susceptibility to antimicrobial agents. The significance of a particular enterococcal isolate is a major factor in determining when antimicrobial testing should be done. Once the need to test a particular isolate has been established, selection of the appropriate antimicrobial agents for testing must be considered based on the site of infection. Testing of antimicrobial agents to which enterococci are intrinsically resistant is contraindicated. The drugs that should not be reported include aminoglycosides at standard concentrations, cephalosporins, clindamycin, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. They may appear active for enterococci in vitro but are not effective clinically, and as such, they should not be reported as susceptible. Updated guidelines (153) for the selection of antimicrobial agents should be followed for routine testing and reporting. The in vitro methods for detecting antimicrobial resistance in enterococcal isolates are reviewed and summarized in references 1 and 152 and are also discussed in chapters 72 and 74.

As already mentioned, testing for high-level aminoglycoside resistance as a predictor of synergy should be done with any enterococcal isolate implicated in infections for which combination therapy is indicated, e.g., from systemic infections. Enterococci are also frequently encountered in polymicrobial infections associated with the gastrointestinal tract or superficial wounds of hospitalized patients. Their pathogenic significance in such settings is uncertain, but susceptibility testing is warranted when predominant or heavy growth is observed. Testing ofE. faecalis isolates from lower urinary tract infections is optional, as these infections usually respond to therapy with ampicillin or nitrofurantoin. However, many hospital infection control programs require routine testing as part of surveillance programs for VRE. For instances in which testing a urinary tract isolate is appropriate, ciprofloxacin, fosfomycin, levofloxacin, norfloxacin, and tetracycline could be selected, in addition to nitrofurantoin and ampicillin (35, 153). In cases of treatment failure, testing is always warranted.
